text: Jennifer it seems to me Republicans got
the better of the deal to avert the
shutdown last week but this week the
debate is shifting toward 2012 budget
and beyond more difficult terrain for
Republicans because they're talking
about big changes in Medicare and
Medicaid how do they see the challenge
ahead of them well I actually think that
the dynamic may play out very similarly
to the one we saw over the short term
solution the spending plan for the rest
of this fiscal year if you listen to
Republicans particularly the freshmen
and the more conservative factions of
their party they say the fight is going
to remain the same we want substantial
changes to Medicaid and Medicare and we
want to continue to cut more spending in
the 2011 budget debate there was an
implicit bottom line which was we are
really going to try very hard to keep
the government open is the implicit
bottom line of this debate despite the
threats is we really are going to raise
the debt ceiling I think if you talk to
the vast majority of Republicans they
would understand the need to do that
because they would understand the
implications on the capital markets
America's ability to borrow and so forth
but I think you will see a lot of
outspoken members talk about their
expectations and their goals and their
requirements to vote that way Wall
Street's a huge complication because
you've got investors saying it would be
crazy not to raise the debt limit but
what a Republicans say about the way
they got hammered in 1995-96 for trying
to cut back Medicare and for President
Bush's attempt to partially privatize
Social Security in 2005 those would seem
to stand for the danger of really
pressing hard for big changes on
benefits affecting seniors right well I
would say two things about 95 visa vie
this class of Republican freshmen
particularly one is that a lot of them
were not in government a lot of them
were in college I mean there was a whole
variety of experiences that had nothing
to do with serving in Washington they
think this is just a completely
different time they don't relate to it
in the way someone like Speaker John
Boehner and others of the more old guard
Republican student John Boehner
definitely relates to yes he relates to
it profound
the other piece of it is that i think
republicans have the debt crisis as
ballast for their argument now that this
is a different time that the fiscal
situation is different that the
globalization the economy is completely
different than it was in 95 and they
have more to work with so does that mean
the republicans are going to pass
through the budget committee this week
the ryan plan without much difficulty
and will it then pass through the house
easily i would imagine that whatever
paul ryan has presented to the
republicans will pass through the house
easily simply because there's a lot of
support for it before there were having
any details out and paul ryan is a real
cult figure in this class they're very
very impressive what he has to say about
entitlements now the president's going
to give a speech on wednesday where he
really joins this argument in a way that
he hasn't in the last several months
what how do people on the hill see the
potential for the president's
involvement to shift the parameters of
the debate I imagine that Republicans
will already will be an attack before
the speech even happens because they'll
be looking at what he presented for his
2012 budget where they say he didn't do
substantial or anything much to attack
entitlement programs so I imagine he's
starting from a place from their view of
too little the President as I say it's
going to open in essence in negotiation
with Republicans butts not at all clear
that the negotiation can or will be
concluded this year or even next year I
don't think Republicans would say
there's not going to be a resolution I
think that's what history could suggest
is the possibility I think Republicans
will stick to the same line of thinking
in the same presentation of their line
of thinking that they did during the
fight to keep the government open this
is what we want and we're not going to
lower our bar and then the bar quietly
gets lowered because in fact they only
control one third of this process well
the one thing we do know is there is
going to be an election in 2012 and
somebody's going to have the upper hand
in this debate that's accelerating this
week thanks Jennifer thank you
you
